Comments_List: Nothing. Im not joking when I say I got nothing out of this class
Basic introduction to imaging techniques and biosensing. Learned how solve problems related to biosensing and imaging. learned how to write research proposal
Learned about the fundamental principles and science behind MRI, PET, fluorescence imaging etc.
Knowledge about basic concepts in Imaging and other biosensors.
The major principle of several biosensing techniques.
Overview of biosensing concepts in MRI
I learned the concept and basic mechanisms of different microscopy methods. The knowledge will be helpful when I use microscopes for my research in the future.
I learned the basic theory and vocabulary behind MRI, PET, FRET, MRS, and bioelectrical sensors.

Strengths - ??? None? 
Weaknesses - a lot, which I will discuss and pray that someone actually reads this review. There is NO REASON this class should be part of the graduate curriculum when half of the graduate students dont do imaging. Not ONE concept I learned this semester will ever be applicable in my research. I hated every moment of this class, and the professors wonder why some students never attend lecture.

Strength- could be useful for students interested in medical imaging
Weakness- sometimes hard to follow the contents. A lot of homework.

Good content, lots of very interesting lecturers, but I wish there was a centralized set of resources to study from/learn. it seemed a little scattered since there wasn't a core text that took us through the whole course, and each lecturer had a different set of notes to go through.
Lectures can be improved.

The lectures were divided into sections based upon the different module of imaging. The different professors teaching the sections were very knowledgeable about the subject. All of the assignments, exams, HWs, and the paper, were all designed to reinforce the concepts covered in the lectures. One weakness of the course was that the assignment deadlines outlined in the syllabus weren't always followed. Sometimes the problem sets would be posted late but the deadlines were also always extended accordingly.
Course material is well organized.
Some content of the course is very difficult for students like me who are from pure biology background without any experience in Bioimaging.

Strengths: This course covers a broad range of topics and introduces enough in each area that students have a jumping off point for researching these subjects in depth.

Weaknesses: It's hard to figure out what is being asked on some of the homework/exam questions. Often the answers are simple, but deciphering the problem takes longer than it should. Or something's been typed incorrectly in the question and that needs to be sussed out. I don't think I understand of the methods covered well enough to use them.
Never. Please stop taking this course so it will get canceled and people will have to take something else.

Yes, i'd recommend it if you're interested in biosensing and imaging. Rothman and Hyder are great and very nice. It may be worth searching through the syllabi of similar courses to make sure that this class contains the content you're hoping for. I heard that there are a number of other courses that cover medical imaging.

Yes, the assignments were very straightforward. Showing up to lecture helped clarify topics but all the lecture notes were posted online and easy to follow. The grading was also fair and the professors were very accessible. If you're curious about the science behind modern medical imaging techniques then this is the class for you.
It is a required course in BME.
I would recommend this course to students who will conduct research in bioimaging in the future.
I would not recommend this course. I think there are other ways to cover this material that are more interesting and lead to deeper understanding.
